channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Mart√≠nez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Why did Israel strike Iran? An Israeli politician and a U.S.-Iran expert weigh in
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Israel's U.N. Ambassador Danny Danon about his country's strikes.

item.title: Copenhagen is adapting to a warmer world with rain tunnels and 'sponge parks'
item.description: Copenhagen is expected to receive 30% more rainfall by the end of the century. The city is responding with a massive long-term adaptation plan.

item.title: RFK Jr. replaced everyone on the CDC's vaccine panel. Here's why that matters
item.description: It plays a big role in deciding which vaccines kids and adults get routinely, what's covered by insurance and which shots are made available free to low-income kids.

item.title: What Israel's strikes on Iran mean for the region
item.description: Three top security chiefs were killed in Iran, including the military's chief of staff. Also hit was Iran's main nuclear enrichment facility. What do Israel's strikes on Iran mean for the stability of the region?

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Israel strikes Iran killing two top military leaders, Democratic Sen. Padilla removed from DHS secretary Kristi Noem's press conference, Congress moves to eliminate federal funding for public media.

item.title: Israel strikes Iran killing two top Iranian military leaders
item.description: Israel has carried out air strikes in Iran, killing two top Iranian military leaders. Secretary of State Marco Rubio said that U.S. forces were not involved in the attack.

item.title: Israel strikes on Iran defy Trump's diplomacy efforts
item.description: NPR's Michel Martin asks U.S.-Iranian relations expert Trita Parsi, executive vice president of the Quincy Institute for Responsible Statecraft, about the motivations behind Israeli airstrikes targeting the country's nuclear sites.

item.title: Author Augustine Sedgewick on his new book, 'Fatherhood'
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with author Augustine Sedgewick about his new book, "Fatherhood," which illustrates as a collective portrait of emblematic fathers throughout history from Aristotle to Bob Dylan.

item.title: Americans will feel impact of immigration enforcement on farms, union president warns
item.description: Workers are "terrified" as immigration agents sweep farms, the president of United Farm Workers says, adding that Americans should think about the "human loss" as well as "crops rotting" in the fields

item.title: Gov. Abbott deploys thousands of troops across Texas ahead of immigration protests
item.description: Texas Gov. Greg Abbott has deployed more than 5,000 Texas National Guard troops and more than 2,000 state police to help local law enforcers manage Saturday protests against the Trump administration.
